IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED
		  STATES

enrolled-dateline.#text: Begun and held at the City of Washington on Thursday, the third day of January, two thousand and thirteen

congress.#text: One Hundred Thirteenth Congress of the United States of America

official-title.#text: To support revitalization and reform of the Organization of American States, and for other purposes.

role.#text: Speaker of the House of Representatives
Vice President of the United States and President of the Senate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Organization of American States Revitalization and Reform Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
Congress makes the following findings:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: recognizes that—

text.#text: The Charter of the
representative democracy is indispensable for the stability, peace, and development of the Western Hemisphere; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is to promote and consolidate representative democracy, with due respect for the principle of nonintervention.

text.#text: a purpose of the
The United States supports the purposes and principles enshrined in—
the Charter of the
the Inter-American Democratic Charter; and
the American Declaration on the Rights and Duties of Man.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: in its efforts with all member states to meet our commitments under the instruments set forth in paragraph (2).

text.#text: The United States supports the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: as it operates in a manner consistent with the Inter-American Democratic Charter.

text.#text: Congress supports the
It is the policy of the United States—
to promote democracy and the rule of law throughout the Western Hemisphere;
to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms in the Western Hemisphere; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the American Declaration on the Rights and Duties of Man, the Inter-American Democratic Charter, and other fundamental instruments of democracy.

text.#text: to support the practices, purposes, and principles expressed in the Charter of the
It is the sense of Congress that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (OAS) should be the primary multi-lateral diplomatic entity for regional dispute resolution and promotion of democratic governance and institutions;

text.#text: the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is a valuable platform from which to launch initiatives aimed to benefit the countries of the Western Hemisphere;

text.#text: the
the Summit of the Americas institution and process embodies a valuable complement to regional dialogue and cooperation;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
, and other Members of the Joint Summit Working Group, and the
should play a central role in overseeing and managing the Summit process;

text.#text: the Summit of the Americas process should be formally and more effectively integrated into the work of the
the OAS General Assembly and the Summit of the Americas events should be combined geographically and chronologically in the years in which they coincide;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has historically accepted too many mandates from its member states, resulting in both lack of clarity on priorities and loss of institutional focus, which in turn has reduced the effectiveness of the organization;

text.#text: the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: should review its core functions no less than annually and seek opportunities to reduce the number of mandates not directly related to its core functions;

text.#text: to ensure an appropriate balance of priorities, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: strengths lie in strengthening peace and security, promoting and consolidating representative democracy, regional dispute resolution, election assistance and monitoring, fostering economic growth and development cooperation, facilitating trade, combating illicit drug trafficking and transnational crime, and support for the Inter-American Human Rights System;

text.#text: key

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the consideration of future mandates;

text.#text: the core competencies referred to in paragraph (8) should remain central to the strategic planning process of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: mandates should be accepted by the member states only after an analysis is conducted and formally presented consisting of a calculation of the financial costs associated with the mandate, an assessment of the comparative advantage of the
in the implementation of the mandate, and a description of the ways in which the mandate advances the organization’s core mission;

text.#text: any new
any new mandates should include, in addition to the analysis described in paragraph (10), an identification of the source of funding to be used to implement the mandate;

transparent and merit-based human resource standards and processes; and

to move toward an assessed fee structure that assures the financial sustainability of the organization and establishes, not later than five years after the date of the enactment of this Act, that no member state pays more than 50 percent of the organization’s assessed fees.
